questions.text: A patient presents with double vision. On examination, there is no adduction to the right and he is diagnosed with left-sided one-and-half syndrome. What is the aetiology behind this disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Lesion of interstitial nucleus of Cajal

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pontine haemorrhage One-and-a-half syndrome consists of ipsilateral conjugate horizontal gaze palsy (referring to the ‘one’) and ipsilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (referring to the ‘half’) and is due to a lesion of the medial longitudinal Fasciculus combined with a lesion of either the abducens nucleus or the Paramedian pontine reticular formation on the same side. Any pontine lesion like pontine hemorrhage can lead to this syndrome.

Highyeild:

The patient's only horizontal eye movement is the abduction of the eye on the other side.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. frontal lobe ischemia presents with hemiplegia, speech abnormalities, personality changes etc and it is not the cause of one and half syndrome. Option: C. lesion in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal causes Supranuclear paresis of upgaze, downgaze, or vertical eye movements, unlike in this case which has horizontal gaze palsy Option: D. Damage to the posterior commissure causes Parinaud's syndrome or dorsal midbrain syndrome, which is a supranuclear vertical gaze disorder.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with an inability to look to his right. He is diagnosed with one-and-a-half syndrome. Which of the following features are seen in this syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Damage to the Medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B Damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus ascending from the abducens nucleus in the pons to the oculomotor nucleus in the midbrain (hence, “internuclear”) causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) . One-and-a-half syndrome consists of INO combined with a lesion of either the abducens nucleus or the paramedian pontine reticular formation on the same side.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. Damage to the dorsal midbrain and its posterior commissure causes Parinaud's syndrome or dorsal midbrain syndrome which is a supranuclear vertical gaze disorder.

questions.text: A patient aged 47 years presents with double vision. After examination, he is diagnosed with right-sided and half syndrome. Which of the following features is seen in this disease?
questions.correct_answer: C. Abduction of the left eye
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abduction of the left eye In one and a half syndrome, the only horizontal eye movement possible is the abduction of the eye on the other side.

Highyeild:

One-and-a-half syndrome consists of ipsilateral conjugate horizontal gaze palsy (referring to the ‘one’) and ipsilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (referring to the ‘half’) and is due to a lesion of the medial longitudinal Fasciculus combined with a lesion of either the abducens nucleus or the Paramedian pontine reticular formation on the same side. Any pontine lesion like pontine hemorrhage can lead to this syndrome.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A & B. Vertical gaze palsy is not seen in one-and-a-half syndrome. Option: D. Adduction of the right eye is not possible due to damage to the right medial longitudinal fasciculus.

Extraedge:

One-and-a-half syndrome consists of INO combined with a lesion of either the abducens nucleus or the paramedian pontine reticular formation on the same side.
